Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Cultivating the IoT-enabled Smart Community (IoT-SITY)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award establishes a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at The University of California - Irvine. The REU Site will host students from across the nation to conduct research during the summer with faculty mentors on topics related to the Internet of Things (IoT) for Smart Communities (IoT-SITY). The Internet of Things is an evolving field of connectivity involving networks of physical devices, sensors and other components, and software that can communicate wirelessly over the Internet. The IoT has enabled the proliferation of small, inexpensive devices that can manipulate and control smart spaces such as homes and offices as well as critical infrastructures such as hospitals and airports. The REU students will investigate exciting applications and explore ways in which we can reliably and safely apply and deploy IoT systems to develop the Smart and Connected Communities of the future. The REU Site plans to recruit a diverse cohort of undergraduate students each summer, including students from groups traditionally under-represented in computing. In addition to their research activities, the students will participate in other professional development activities that will prepare them to pursue exciting careers in computer science and engineering including leading the technology research and development of the future.

The REU site is led a team of accomplished faculty mentors from the School of Information and Computer Sciences and the School of Engineering at the University of California-Irvine. The affiliated research laboratories provide students with opportunities to use state-of-the-art equipment and facilities to explore topics that are current and timely. Together, these faculty members will provide an exciting and enriching environment which cultivates inquiry and excitement about learning while developing the students' research skills and interests. IoT-SITY participants will be able to apply computer science and engineering to the next generation of IoT technologies for smart communities, smart spaces, and smart infrastructures. The students will gain the knowledge base for creating IoT devices and understanding design considerations, constraints, and interfaces between the physical world and IoT research. The project has the potential to contribute to the body of emerging research in computer science will preparing students for the computing workforce of tomorrow.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes: This award established a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at The University of California - Irvine. The REU Site hosted 27 students from across the nation to conduct research during the summer with faculty mentors on topics related to the Internet of Things (IoT) for Smart Communities (IoT-SITY). The Internet of Things is an evolving field of connectivity involving networks of physical devices, sensors and other components, and software that can communicate wirelessly over the Internet. The IoT has enabled the proliferation of small, inexpensive devices that can manipulate and control smart spaces such as homes and offices as well as critical infrastructures such as hospitals, airports, smart water systems and intelligent transportation networks. Each REU student had an independent project investigating exciting applications and explored ways in which we can reliably and safely apply and deploy IoT systems to develop the Smart and Connected Communities of the future. The REU Site recruited a diverse cohort of undergraduate students each summer, including students from groups traditionally under-represented in computing. In addition to their research activities, the students participated in other professional development activities that prepared them to pursue exciting careers in computer science and engineering including leading the technology research and development of the future.

The REU site included seven faculty mentors from the School of Information and Computer Sciences and the School of Engineering at the University of California-Irvine. The affiliated research laboratories provide students with opportunities to use state-of-the-art equipment and facilities to explore topics that were current and timely. Together, these faculty members provided an exciting and enriching environment where students were able to develop their research skills and interests. IoT-SITY participants were able to apply computer science and engineering to the next generation of IoT technologies for smart communities, smart spaces, and smart infrastructures. The students gained the knowledge base for creating IoT devices and understanding design considerations, constraints, and interfaces between the physical world and IoT research. Their projects also contributed to the body of emerging research in computer science.

Intellectual Merit: The REU Site cultivated undergraduate students’ computer science and engineering knowledge and skills by early hands-on involvement in IoT-themed projects in cutting-edge research laboratories. IoT-SITY participants were able to apply computer science and engineering to the next generation of IoT technologies for smart communities, smart spaces, and smart infrastructures. Students also gained the knowledge base for creating IoT devices and understanding design considerations, constraints and interfacing between the physical world and IoT research.

Broader Impacts: The  IoT-SITY REU Site trained 27 computing and engineering undergraduate students. Among this group, 70% (19) were from underrepresented groups – 48% women (13) and 33% students of color (9). These students learned how to effectively apply emerging IoT technologies and gained critical preparation for applying to graduate programs and intellectual confidence to aspire to graduate school training and professional careers in computing and engineering. To date, 89% (24) past participants have earned their bachelor’s degree in a STEM major; 33% (9) are either enrolled in graduate school or have earned a graduate degree in a STEM major; and 11% are still enrolled in a bachelors’ program.
